title: Fake Chrome Setup Leads to NetSupportManager RAT and Mars Stealer

sentences: The victim downloaded and executed a fake Chrome installer (chromesetup.iso) from >hxxps[:]//googleglstatupdt[.]com/LEND/ChromeSetup.iso.<crlf>The ISO contains chromesetup.exe. When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.A shortcut is also added to the users startup directory for persistence. Figure 1 Endpoint view of NetSupportManager execution and decoy payload. Using the NetSupportManager RAT session, the threat actor copied obfuscated scripts with a .wmd extension that are responsible for creating a renamed AutoIT binary and an loading an obfuscated version of Mars Stealer from %TEMP%/IXP<3-digit number> .TMP. One of the obfuscated scripts contains an embedded payload encrypted with RC4 using the hardcoded key 344868553478223918282826525 (Figure 2).Figure 2 Snippets from AutoIT script showing embedded payload and decryption routine. Once loaded, Mars Stealer performs several HTTP requests to retrieve configuration and DLL (Dynamic Link Library) files required for Mars Stealer to operate successfully and upload stolen data (Figure 3).Figure 3 Mars Stealer network communications. Lastly, Base64 decoded part of the configuration retrieved from /7AgkTb5xcS.php: 1|1|1|1|0|5qDlPuVKoR|Telegram|0|%APPDATA%\Telegram Desktop\tdata\|*D877F783D5D3EF8C*,*map*,*configs*|1|0|0|rdp|3|%DESKTOP%\ |*.rdp|0|1|0|cer|3|%DESKTOP%\|*.cer|0|1|0<crlf>When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.<crlf>NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.<crlf>A shortcut is also added to the users startup directory for persistence.<crlf>Using the NetSupportManager RAT session, the threat actor copied obfuscated scripts with a .wmd extension that are responsible for creating a renamed AutoIT binary and an loading an obfuscated version of Mars Stealer from %TEMP%/IXP<3-digit number> .TMP.<crlf>One of the obfuscated scripts contains an embedded payload encrypted with RC4 using the hardcoded key 344868553478223918282826525 (Figure 2).<crlf>Once loaded, Mars Stealer performs several HTTP requests to retrieve configuration and DLL (Dynamic Link Library) files required for Mars Stealer to operate successfully and upload stolen data (Figure 3).<crlf>Lastly, Base64 decoded part of the configuration retrieved from /7AgkTb5xcS.php: 1|1|1|1|0|5qDlPuVKoR|Telegram|0|%APPDATA%\Telegram Desktop\tdata\|*D877F783D5D3EF8C*,*map*,*configs*|1|0|0|rdp|3|%DESKTOP%\ |*.rdp|0|1|0|cer|3|%DESKTOP%\|*.cer|0|1|0

Fake Chrome Setup Leads to NetSupportManager RAT and Mars Stealer
Summary of the Incident

sentences: An information stealing malware called Mars Stealer in a customers environment within the consumer services industry.

In June 2022, Mars Stealer was advertised on XSS, the Russian-language criminal forum, by MarsTeam for $140/month or $800 for a lifetime subscription.<crlf>Mars Stealers capabilities include:Cryptocurrency theft (Our software was developed taking into account the wishes of people working in crypto, so at Mars you can find everything you need to work with crypto and more. MarsTeam post on XSS forum). The stealer supports dozens of popular browser plugins for popular cryptocurrency platforms, such as Coinbase. Additionally, in December 2021, MarsTeam announced the release of Mars ClipboardChanger, which substitutes crypto wallet addresses in the victims clipboard cache to hijack payments.Data theft from major web browsers, including two-factor authentication (2FA) Chrome-based browser extensions (Collects passwords, cookies, cc, autocomplete, browsing history, file download history. - MarsTeam post on XSS forum).Profiling or fingerprinting the infected system.Exfiltrating files from the infected system.<crlf>Cryptocurrency theft (Our software was developed taking into account the wishes of people working in crypto, so at Mars you can find everything you need to work with crypto and more. MarsTeam post on XSS forum). The stealer supports dozens of popular browser plugins for popular cryptocurrency platforms, such as Coinbase. Additionally, in December 2021, MarsTeam announced the release of Mars ClipboardChanger, which substitutes crypto wallet addresses in the victims clipboard cache to hijack payments.<crlf>The stealer supports dozens of popular browser plugins for popular cryptocurrency platforms, such as Coinbase.<crlf>Additionally, in December 2021, MarsTeam announced the release of Mars ClipboardChanger, which substitutes crypto wallet addresses in the victims clipboard cache to hijack payments.<crlf>Data theft from major web browsers, including two-factor authentication (2FA) Chrome-based browser extensions (Collects passwords, cookies, cc, autocomplete, browsing history, file download history. - MarsTeam post on XSS forum).<crlf>Profiling or fingerprinting the infected system.<crlf>Exfiltrating files from the infected system.

The victim downloaded and executed a fake Chrome installer (chromesetup.iso) from >hxxps[:]//googleglstatupdt[.]com/LEND/ChromeSetup.iso.<crlf>The ISO contains chromesetup.exe. When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.A shortcut is also added to the users startup directory for persistence. Figure 1 Endpoint view of NetSupportManager execution and decoy payload. Using the NetSupportManager RAT session, the threat actor copied obfuscated scripts with a .wmd extension that are responsible for creating a renamed AutoIT binary and an loading an obfuscated version of Mars Stealer from %TEMP%/IXP<3-digit number> .TMP. One of the obfuscated scripts contains an embedded payload encrypted with RC4 using the hardcoded key 344868553478223918282826525 (Figure 2).Figure 2 Snippets from AutoIT script showing embedded payload and decryption routine. Once loaded, Mars Stealer performs several HTTP requests to retrieve configuration and DLL (Dynamic Link Library) files required for Mars Stealer to operate successfully and upload stolen data (Figure 3).Figure 3 Mars Stealer network communications. Lastly, Base64 decoded part of the configuration retrieved from /7AgkTb5xcS.php: 1|1|1|1|0|5qDlPuVKoR|Telegram|0|%APPDATA%\Telegram Desktop\tdata\|*D877F783D5D3EF8C*,*map*,*configs*|1|0|0|rdp|3|%DESKTOP%\ |*.rdp|0|1|0|cer|3|%DESKTOP%\|*.cer|0|1|0<crlf>When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.<crlf>NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.<crlf>A shortcut is also added to the users startup directory for persistence.<crlf>Using the NetSupportManager RAT session, the threat actor copied obfuscated scripts with a .wmd extension that are responsible for creating a renamed AutoIT binary and an loading an obfuscated version of Mars Stealer from %TEMP%/IXP<3-digit number> .TMP.<crlf>One of the obfuscated scripts contains an embedded payload encrypted with RC4 using the hardcoded key 344868553478223918282826525 (Figure 2).<crlf>Once loaded, Mars Stealer performs several HTTP requests to retrieve configuration and DLL (Dynamic Link Library) files required for Mars Stealer to operate successfully and upload stolen data (Figure 3).<crlf>Lastly, Base64 decoded part of the configuration retrieved from /7AgkTb5xcS.php: 1|1|1|1|0|5qDlPuVKoR|Telegram|0|%APPDATA%\Telegram Desktop\tdata\|*D877F783D5D3EF8C*,*map*,*configs*|1|0|0|rdp|3|%DESKTOP%\ |*.rdp|0|1|0|cer|3|%DESKTOP%\|*.cer|0|1|0

Drive-by attacks involving malware masquerading as legitimate software are becoming increasingly common since they require no exploits and rely on a victim running code on the attackers behalf.<crlf>Mars Stealer has seen continued development since its release, and targets a wide array of credentials, particularly those used for cryptocurrency exchanges.<crlf>Identifying information stealing malware as early as possible is critical to minimize losses from fraud and hijacked accounts.

sentences: Drive-by attacks involving malware masquerading as legitimate software are becoming increasingly common since they require no exploits and rely on a victim running code on the attackers behalf.<crlf>Mars Stealer has seen continued development since its release, and targets a wide array of credentials, particularly those used for cryptocurrency exchanges.<crlf>Identifying information stealing malware as early as possible is critical to minimize losses from fraud and hijacked accounts.
titles: What can you learn from this TRU positive?

sentences: The victim downloaded and executed a fake Chrome installer (chromesetup.iso) from >hxxps[:]//googleglstatupdt[.]com/LEND/ChromeSetup.iso.<crlf>The ISO contains chromesetup.exe. When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.A shortcut is also added to the users startup directory for persistence. Figure 1 Endpoint view of NetSupportManager execution and decoy payload. Using the NetSupportManager RAT session, the threat actor copied obfuscated scripts with a .wmd extension that are responsible for creating a renamed AutoIT binary and an loading an obfuscated version of Mars Stealer from %TEMP%/IXP<3-digit number> .TMP. One of the obfuscated scripts contains an embedded payload encrypted with RC4 using the hardcoded key 344868553478223918282826525 (Figure 2).Figure 2 Snippets from AutoIT script showing embedded payload and decryption routine. Once loaded, Mars Stealer performs several HTTP requests to retrieve configuration and DLL (Dynamic Link Library) files required for Mars Stealer to operate successfully and upload stolen data (Figure 3).Figure 3 Mars Stealer network communications. Lastly, Base64 decoded part of the configuration retrieved from /7AgkTb5xcS.php: 1|1|1|1|0|5qDlPuVKoR|Telegram|0|%APPDATA%\Telegram Desktop\tdata\|*D877F783D5D3EF8C*,*map*,*configs*|1|0|0|rdp|3|%DESKTOP%\ |*.rdp|0|1|0|cer|3|%DESKTOP%\|*.cer|0|1|0<crlf>When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). sentences: The victim downloaded and executed a fake Chrome installer (chromesetup.iso) from >hxxps[:]//googleglstatupdt[.]com/LEND/ChromeSetup.iso.<crlf>The ISO contains chromesetup.exe. When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.A shortcut is also added to the users startup directory for persistence. Figure 1 Endpoint view of NetSupportManager execution and decoy payload. Using the NetSupportManager RAT session, the threat actor copied obfuscated scripts with a .wmd extension that are responsible for creating a renamed AutoIT binary and an loading an obfuscated version of Mars Stealer from %TEMP%/IXP<3-digit number> .TMP. One of the obfuscated scripts contains an embedded payload encrypted with RC4 using the hardcoded key 344868553478223918282826525 (Figure 2).Figure 2 Snippets from AutoIT script showing embedded payload and decryption routine. Once loaded, Mars Stealer performs several HTTP requests to retrieve configuration and DLL (Dynamic Link Library) files required for Mars Stealer to operate successfully and upload stolen data (Figure 3).Figure 3 Mars Stealer network communications. Lastly, Base64 decoded part of the configuration retrieved from /7AgkTb5xcS.php: 1|1|1|1|0|5qDlPuVKoR|Telegram|0|%APPDATA%\Telegram Desktop\tdata\|*D877F783D5D3EF8C*,*map*,*configs*|1|0|0|rdp|3|%DESKTOP%\ |*.rdp|0|1|0|cer|3|%DESKTOP%\|*.cer|0|1|0<crlf>When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.<crlf>NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.<crlf>A shortcut is also added to the users startup directory for persistence.<crlf>Using the NetSupportManager RAT session, the threat actor copied obfuscated scripts with a .wmd extension that are responsible for creating a renamed AutoIT binary and an loading an obfuscated version of Mars Stealer from %TEMP%/IXP<3-digit number> .TMP.<crlf>One of the obfuscated scripts contains an embedded payload encrypted with RC4 using the hardcoded key 344868553478223918282826525 (Figure 2).<crlf>Once loaded, Mars Stealer performs several HTTP requests to retrieve configuration and DLL (Dynamic Link Library) files required for Mars Stealer to operate successfully and upload stolen data (Figure 3).<crlf>Lastly, Base64 decoded part of the configuration retrieved from /7AgkTb5xcS.php: 1|1|1|1|0|5qDlPuVKoR|Telegram|0|%APPDATA%\Telegram Desktop\tdata\|*D877F783D5D3EF8C*,*map*,*configs*|1|0|0|rdp|3|%DESKTOP%\ |*.rdp|0|1|0|cer|3|%DESKTOP%\|*.cer|0|1|0

The victim downloaded and executed a fake Chrome installer (chromesetup.iso) from >hxxps[:]//googleglstatupdt[.]com/LEND/ChromeSetup.iso.<crlf>The ISO contains chromesetup.exe. When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.A shortcut is also added to the users startup directory for persistence. Figure 1 Endpoint view of NetSupportManager execution and decoy payload. Using the NetSupportManager RAT session, the threat actor copied obfuscated scripts with a .wmd extension that are responsible for creating a renamed AutoIT binary and an loading an obfuscated version of Mars Stealer from %TEMP%/IXP<3-digit number> .TMP. One of the obfuscated scripts contains an embedded payload encrypted with RC4 using the hardcoded key 344868553478223918282826525 (Figure 2).Figure 2 Snippets from AutoIT script showing embedded payload and decryption routine. Once loaded, Mars Stealer performs several HTTP requests to retrieve configuration and DLL (Dynamic Link Library) files required for Mars Stealer to operate successfully and upload stolen data (Figure 3).Figure 3 Mars Stealer network communications. Lastly, Base64 decoded part of the configuration retrieved from /7AgkTb5xcS.php: 1|1|1|1|0|5qDlPuVKoR|Telegram|0|%APPDATA%\Telegram Desktop\tdata\|*D877F783D5D3EF8C*,*map*,*configs*|1|0|0|rdp|3|%DESKTOP%\ |*.rdp|0|1|0|cer|3|%DESKTOP%\|*.cer|0|1|0<crlf>When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). In TRU Positives, eSentires Threat Response Unit (TRU) provides a summary of a recent threat investigation. We outline how we responded to the confirmed threat and what recommendations we have going forward.
An information stealing malware called Mars Stealer in a customers environment within the consumer services industry.

The victim downloaded and executed a fake Chrome installer (chromesetup.iso) from >hxxps[:]//googleglstatupdt[.]com/LEND/ChromeSetup.iso.<crlf>The ISO contains chromesetup.exe. When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.A shortcut is also added to the users startup directory for persistence. Figure 1 Endpoint view of NetSupportManager execution and decoy payload. Using the NetSupportManager RAT session, the threat actor copied obfuscated scripts with a .wmd extension that are responsible for creating a renamed AutoIT binary and an loading an obfuscated version of Mars Stealer from %TEMP%/IXP<3-digit number> .TMP. One of the obfuscated scripts contains an embedded payload encrypted with RC4 using the hardcoded key 344868553478223918282826525 (Figure 2).Figure 2 Snippets from AutoIT script showing embedded payload and decryption routine. Once loaded, Mars Stealer performs several HTTP requests to retrieve configuration and DLL (Dynamic Link Library) files required for Mars Stealer to operate successfully and upload stolen data (Figure 3).Figure 3 Mars Stealer network communications. Lastly, Base64 decoded part of the configuration retrieved from /7AgkTb5xcS.php: 1|1|1|1|0|5qDlPuVKoR|Telegram|0|%APPDATA%\Telegram Desktop\tdata\|*D877F783D5D3EF8C*,*map*,*configs*|1|0|0|rdp|3|%DESKTOP%\ |*.rdp|0|1|0|cer|3|%DESKTOP%\|*.cer|0|1|0<crlf>When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). The victim downloaded and executed a fake Chrome installer (chromesetup.iso) from >hxxps[:]//googleglstatupdt[.]com/LEND/ChromeSetup.iso.<crlf>The ISO contains chromesetup.exe. When manually executed by the victim, the fake setup process initializes the NetSupportManager RAT (remote access tool) and the legitimate Chrome setup as a decoy (Figure 1). NetSupportManager is commonly used to remotely control systems for malicious purposes.A shortcut is also added to the users startup directory for persistence. Figure 1 Endpoint view of NetSupportManager execution and decoy payload. Using the NetSupportManager RAT session, the threat actor copied obfuscated scripts with a .wmd extension that are responsible for creating a renamed AutoIT binary and an loading an obfuscated version of Mars Stealer from %TEMP%/IXP<3-digit number> .TMP. One of the obfuscated scripts contains an embedded payload encrypted with RC4 using the hardcoded key 344868553478223918282826525 (Figure 2).Figure 2 Snippets from AutoIT script showing embedded payload and decryption routine. Once loaded, Mars Stealer performs several HTTP requests to retrieve configuration and DLL (Dynamic Link Library) files required for Mars Stealer to operate successfully and upload stolen data (Figure 3).Figure 3 Mars Stealer network communications. In TRU Positives, eSentires Threat Response Unit (TRU) provides a summary of a recent threat investigation. We outline how we responded to the confirmed threat and what recommendations we have going forward.
titles: What can you learn from this TRU positive?
Recommendations from our Threat Response Unit (TRU) Team:

associated: MDR for Endpoint identified the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) associated with NetSupportManager RAT and AutoIT malware deployment.

Increase awareness of social engineering threat tactics with your users through phishing and security awareness training.Ensure users are aware of risks associated with downloading applications from the web
Ensure users are aware of risks associated with downloading applications from the web
targets: Mars Stealer has seen continued development since its release, and targets a wide array of credentials, particularly those used for cryptocurrency exchanges
